awd_titl_txt: AgriSense:  Multichannel disposable sensors for animal health disease diagnostics
awd_abstract_narration: 1264705(Vogel). Rapid and sensitive detection of bovine respiratory disease (BRD)-associated viral infections in live animals is recognized as key to minimizing the impact of this disease. Currently, the most common method of serological diagnosis is fluorescently labeled ELISAs. ELISA-based testing is limited as it typically relies on the detection of a single viral antibody subtype within an individual test sample per ELISA plate, the testing is relatively slow (up to 1 week) and expensive (~$5 per test). A low-cost multiplexed platform capable of detecting several antibody markers related to BRD infections in the same test assay would offer significant economic benefits for routine serological testing. Additionally, rapid on-farm ?cowside? multiplexed diagnostic capabilities would be a major step forward towards more efficient and effective management, control and/or eradication of BRD-associated pathogens. At present there is no electronic field based test for disease diagnostics available commercially for the animal health sector, let alone for BRD.  Our team will address these challenges by building inexpensive electrochemical sensors for detection of biomarkers associated with BRD infection.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
In response to the U.S.-Ireland R&D Partnership program  in which the National Science Foundation, Science Foundation Ireland, and Invest Northern Ireland jointly fund collaborative research programs, AgriSense focused on the fundamental understanding, design and development of a novel low-cost and label-free, integrated multichannel potentiometric/electrochemical impedance biosensor, for cheap flexible substrates, that is suitable for use in animal health and disease diagnostic applications with a focus on diagnosis of Bovine Respiratory Disease (BRD). This disease complex results in an annual total economic loss to the US agri-food industry of over $2 billion. Due to the highly virulent and contagious nature of the disease, segregation of diseased animals at a very early stage is essential  to prevent further infection within a herd. A key challenge to disease mitigation is that current lab-based testing (enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay, ELISA) are both expensive ($5 per viral agent) and can take up to a week to be processed at commercial labs. To address this challenge, the AgriSense sensor system targeted the fundamental challenges associated with development of a field-deployable device for simultaneous multiplexed sensing of primary viral agents (involved in the development of BRD) with required sensitivity and short assay times. The team employed the expertise and capabilities of researchers at the Georgia Institute of Technology (GT) (potentiometric sensing), Tyndall National Institute at University College Cork in Ireland (electroimpedance sensing) and Queen’s University Belfast in Northern Ireland (antigen production).

 

Intellectual Merit

One of the most significant results of the project was the demonstration of potentiometric-based sensing of bovine herpesvirus-1 (BHV-1) antibody in real serum samples from cattle (A. Tarasov, D. W. Gray, M.-Y. Tsai, N. Shields, A. Montrose, N. Creedon, P. Lovera, A. O'Riordan, M. H. Mooney, E. M. Vogel, “A potentiometric biosensor for rapid on-site disease diagnostics,” Biosensors and Bioelectronics 79, 669-678, 2016). BHV-1 is a key antibody associated with BRD. The electronic sensor results showed sensitivity equivalent to ELISA but the measurements were performed in minutes rather than days.

A second significant result was the demonstration an integrated system that combines potentiometric and impedimetric biosensors using the same sensing surface (M. Y. Tsai, N. Creedon, E. Brightbill, S. Pavlidis, B. Brown, D. W. Gray, N. Shields, R. Sayers, M. H. Mooney, A. O'Riordan, and E. M. Vogel, "Direct correlation between potentiometric and impedance biosensing of antibody- antigen interactions using an integrated system," Applied Physics Letters 111, 073701, 2017). Interestingly, experimental and theoretical results suggest that both potentiometric and impedance biosensors are sensitive to the same fundamental mechanism, namely the change of surface potential due to the attachment of charged biomolecules. Therefore, potentiometric biosensors are inherently sufficient as electrical transducers for label-free biomolecule detection, while providing the added benefits of rapid response and low-cost scalability.

A third significant result was the comparison of graphene-based potentiometric biosensors to established sensor technology (A. Tarasov, M.-Y. Tsai, E. M. Flynn, C. A. Joiner, R. C. Taylor and E. M. Vogel, "Gold-coated graphene field-effect transistors for quantitative analysis of protein–antibody interactions," 2D Materials 2, 044008, 2015). The results showed that while the active interface in contact with the electrolyte determined the sensor response and selectivity, the choice of the readout transducer mainly influences the noise limit, and, hence, the signal-to-noise ratio. Given the mechanical stability and low noise figure of graphene, graphene transistors are ideal candidates for flexible, low-cost and high-performance transducers for biosensing.

 

Broader Impacts

This project has provided significant broader impacts in terms of opportunities for graduate students, undergraduate students and high school students. Mr. Meng-yen Tsai (a GT PhD student) spent three weeks in Ireland working on the project providing an in-depth international experience. Three PhD researchers from University College Cork and Queen's University Belfast also spent 2 weeks at Georgia Tech interacting with both Meng-yen and a second GT PhD student on the project, Ms. Eleanor Brightbill.

Mr. Robert Taylor (an African-American sophomore at GT) received a GT School of Materials Science and Engineering (MSE) research scholarship to work on this project. Mr. Mohammed Nur (an undergraduate from the University of Bufallo) received a Semiconductor Research Corporation (SRC) fellowship for a 2015 summer internship in my group. These two undergraduates began the development of transitioning the potentiometric sensors to flexible paper substrates. Robert wrote a report and gave a poster presentation at the GT MSE Research Fair. Mohammed gave a poster at the annual SRC technical conference. Ms. Bryce Hitchcock and Ms. Erin Flynn (GT undergraduates) each also worked on the project for approximately one year. Erin and Robert were both co-authors on an archival publication.
